s.text: Of course, the paper should have mentioned that this hardly counts against the idea of streamlining bureaucracy--it only shows that not all reinventions are equally good ones.

There is one other recurring difference in the papers' Germany coverage: all but the NYT render the winner's name "Schroeder," while the Ochs Sulzberger bund foregoes that "oe" for an "o" under an umlaut.

There is one other recurring difference in the papers' Germany coverage: all but the NYT render the winner's name "Schroeder," while the Ochs Sulzberger bund foregoes that "oe" for an "o" under an umlaut.

There is one other recurring difference in the papers' Germany coverage: all but the NYT render the winner's name "Schroeder," while the Ochs Sulzberger bund foregoes that "oe" for an "o" under an umlaut.

The big concern, says USAT , is the flooding that is likely when the storm hits New Orleans, where tens of thousands of residents have taken shelter in such locales as the Superdome and the convention center.
The WP cites both the "new face" and unemployment angles.
The LAT says that "Schroeder's policies differ little from those of Kohl--and his election expressed a hunger for a new face more than a new direction."

The sort of story that, post-Monica, has been far too scarce appears today on the LAT front: the paper's long-time defense business reporter Ralph Vartabedian reports that new government information out today shows that the Pentagon still can't protect itself against embezzlement and overpayment.

The Post says that getting very little attention beneath all the Monica mayhem are special provisions that have added billions to the defense bill, and hundreds of millions to the veterans and housing bill and to the energy bill, to name a few.
